block.p: Rankings reflect sales, for the week ended April 14, at many thousands of venues where a wide range of general interest books are sold nationwide. These include hundreds of independent book retailers (statistically weighted to represent all such outlets); national, regional and local chains; online and multimedia entertainment retailers; university, gift, supermarket, discount, department stores and newsstands. An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
Editor's Choice Other recent books of particular interest

THE GRAND SURPRISE: The Journals of Leo Lerman. Edited by Stephen Pascal. (Knopf, $37.50.) Lerman, a contemporary of Truman Capote, was a larger-than-life figure in the magazine world who also gave great parties.

DEEP ECONOMY: The Wealth of Communities and the Durable Future, by Bill McKibben. (Times Books/Holt, $25.) The noted environmentalist aims to change attitudes about economics and consumption in an age of global warming.

... AND I HAVEN'T HAD A BAD DAY SINCE: From the Streets of Harlem to the Halls of Congress, by Charles B. Rangel with Leon Wynter. (Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's, $24.95.) This memoir from the chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee brims with brio.
THE WILD TREES: A Story of Passion and Daring, by Richard Preston. (Random House, $25.95.) The strange biological world at the tops of giant redwoods obsesses a group of climbers.
BLACK & WHITE, by Dani Shapiro. (Knopf, $24.) The protagonist of Shapiro's novel is driven into exile by the notoriety of the raw art photos her famous mother made of her as a child.
EASTER EVERYWHERE: A Memoir, by Darcey Steinke. (Bloomsbury, $24.95.) A minister's daughter confronts her own spiritual rootlessness.
WAY MORE WEST: New and Selected Poems, by Edward Dorn. Edited by Michael Rothenberg. (Penguin Poets; paper, $20.) Dorn, who died in 1999, was the quintessential Black Mountain poet.

BURIED IN THE BITTER WATERS: The Hidden History of Racial Cleansing in America, by Elliot Jaspin. (Basic Books, $26.95.) A troubling investigation of a dozen locales that engineered mass expulsions of blacks from 1890 to 1930.
HUNK CITY, by James Wilcox. (Viking, $25.95.) The globalized marketplace has pressed its thumb on Tula Springs, La., the town Wilcox introduced in his 1983 novel, ''Modern Baptists.''

ANT FARM: And Other Desperate Situations, by Simon Rich. (Random House, $12.95.) Very short, very sweet Monty Python-esque humor vignettes from a former Harvard Lampoon president.The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.
